cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: The following steamers are expected to leave Port Said on or about the following dates:--
Port-Said to London via Brindisi
The BRINDISI steamer leaves PORT-SAID after arrival of Indian Mail. Combined steamer and sleeping car fare from PORT-SAID to LONDON via BRINDISI or via MARSEILLES £25.9.11
To the East.

The Mail Steamers leave SUEZ for ADEN and BOMBAY every Wednesday, and for AUSTRALIA and CHINA every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for CALCUTTA, fortnightly, and another for JAPAN. Passengers can embark at PORT-SAID.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Belgrade, Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
Steamers leave Suez every Thursday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, calling as required at TOR
(for Mount Sinai) and YAMBO, and continuing in alternate weeks to SUAKIM, MASSOWAH,HODEIDAH, and ADEN.
N.B. Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive inspected his estates yesterday at Mariout, and returned in the evening to .Montazah palace, where he is spending today. The Gonvernorat of Cairo has issued invitations to numerous officials and notables to present themselves at the station at 11.30 a.m. next Tuesday to greet hisHighness on his arrival. The Ministry of War has given orders for a detachment to be' present as a guard of () The train in which his Highness travels will stop at Damanhour, Tantah, (Buket el) San, and Benha.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL.
div.p: Largest 1 class and most comfortable hotel in Alexandria. Facing the sea Central position. Under English management. 81.11.94

div.p: CAIRO.
Open all the year round.
ELECTRIC LIGHT, —LIFT, —MODERATE CHARGES
RAMADAN begins on Tuesday next.
THE SLEENAN BASE is to be heard at Alexandria by Judge Saumarez on the 10th inst.

div.head: LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL.-
div.p: The next meeting of the Legislative Council is not expected to take place before December 1.

div.head: AMERICAN MISSION.-
div.p: The English services in Tantah under the auspices of the American Mission will be resumed next Sabbath, 6th inst., at 11 a.m., and will be held as formerly once every two weeks.

div.head: SHOOTING OUTRAGE.
div.p: The director of the sugar factory at Bibeh has been fired at and slightly wounded while standing by his window in the evening. A dissatisfied or dismissed workman is believed to have been guilty of the crime.

div.head: NEW LINER.
div.p: Another new steamer (called the Braco, a sister ship to the Milo) for the Bell's Asia Minor S.S. Company, arrived at Alexandria from Hull and the Syrian Coast yesterday. She is commanded by Capt. J. McLaren, this being the second steamer which he has brought out from home.

div.head: PROFITABLE PASTIME.-
div.p: It is not only the wish to learn quickly which urges so many to go to the Berlitz Schools, but also the prospect of taking an hour's lesson in the most agreeable way. For example, many ladies take lessons simply for pleasure a very useful pastime. A trial lesson in English, French, or any other language may be had at Alexandria, 26, Rue Eglise Copte, or at Cairo, 1, Sharia Kamel. [ADVT.]

div.head: THE PYRAMIDS.-
div.p: Visitors to the Pyramids will be pleased to learn that an attempt is being made to meet the requirements of the "inner man" in this locality. A bar and restaurant have been opened where tea, etc., can be obtained at moderate prices. All the refreshments are supplied by Mr. Spathis, the well-known merchant and mineral water manufacturer, and this is a sufficient guarantee of their high quality.

THE NEW NORDDEUTSCHER LLOYD'Imperial Mail steamer Prinz Eitel Friedrich, a description of which we, gave in a recent issue, left Suez yesterday morning, bound to China. She had a full first and second-class passenger list, which included 17 naval officers, 32 cadets, and 10 non-commissioned officers, reliefs for the German squadron in the Far East. There were also on board 17 Belgian soldiers in charge of an officer, bound for China.

H.M. TRANSPORT Soudan (Capt. S. de B. Lockyer, R.N.R.) arrived at Port Said on Tuesday from Bombay for Malta and Southampton. There were 1,362 of all ranks on board, including the Cheshire Regiment, numbering 427 officers and men, who are to be stationed at Lichfield on their arrival in England. Sixty-nine details are to land at Malta. The officer commanding the troops is Lt. Col. Hardy, Cheshire Regt.

div.head: COQUELIN AINE.
div.p: Coquelin Ainé makes his debut at the Zizinia Theatre tomorrow evening in Molière's comedy Tartufe, in which he will play the title role. It will be interesting if we give a few particulars of the great French actor's life. Coquelin Ainé is the son of a baker, and was destined originally to follow that trade. but evincing a great aptitude for the stage, he went to Paris and was admitted to the Conservatoire on December 29, 1859, joining M. Regnier's class, of which he became the most brilliant pupil. He obtained the second prize for comedy, and made his debut at the Théâtre Français on December 7, 1860, in the character of Gros-René in the "Dépit Amoureux." He afterwards played with success in the "Fourberies de Scapin," "Mariage de Figaro," "Don Juan," and other classical pieces; Lupin in "La Mère Confidente; the Marquis in "Le Joueur;" Annibal in "L'Aventurière," He created the role of Anatole in "Une Loge d'Opera," John in "Trop Curieux," Gagneux in "Jean Baudry," Vincent in "L'Eillet Blanc," Aristide in "Le Lion Amoureux," Gringoire in the play of that name, Beaubourg in "Paul Forestier," Eucrate in "Le Coq de Mycille," M. Coquelin has obtained great success in society by reciting in private and at public meetings, and has thus added to the reputation of new poets, particularly of Eugène Manuel and François Coppée. In 1886 he was put on the list of "societaires pensionnaires" of the Theatre Français, and this prevented him from appearing as an actor in any French theatre. But, after travelling abroad in America and Alsace at the head of a dramatic company of his own formation, he re-entered the Comedie Française in December, 1889, and played Mascarille, Diafoirus, and Argente, and other parts, in order to support his son Jean, at that time making his first appearances as an actor. He created the part of Labussière in M. Sardou's "Thermidor," which after three representations was interdicted by the French Government His next creation was (January 25, 1891). Petruccio in a modified version of the "Taming of the Shrew" (Nov. 1892). As his engagement at the Theatre Français lasts only six months each year, he has recently taken to touring abroad with a company of his own selection, and in the summer of 1892 he brought "Thermi- dor" and "La Megère Apprivoisée" to London. He is the author of several works on the comedian's art.

div.head: THE KOM OMBO CO.
div.p: A GREAT UNDERTAKING.

We have been favoured with some interest- ing details regarding the progress being made by the Kom Ombo Company, which is engaged in undertaking the development of the great plain extending from the Nile to Giebel Silsileh. The undertaking is financed by Sir Ernest. Cassel and Messrs. Suares and Cattaui. The concession extends to 120,000 feddans, with the option of taking up another 40,000 feddans at a slightly higher level, which is now about to be surveyed.
A correspondent, writing on the subject, says:

The work which is now being done at Kom Ombo is one of the most important under- takings which has ever been attempted in this country. The Suez Canal and the Assouan Dam may take precedence of it, but, for my part, I have no objection to stating that the work now being taken in hand at Kom Ombo is fully entitled to take the third place. Nobody, who has not visited and personally inspected the works, can have the slightest conception of their magnitude and of the enormous task, which has been undertaken in order to make this huge desert plain a smiling area of cultivated land. It is a great pity that the disaster of last year, when the pumping building tumbled down, should have greatly impeded the work. At present the pamping installation is being rapidly developed. The levelling of the land, the making of canals, the laying of the piping, and the many other odd jobs, necessitated by such a gigantic undertaking, are being rapidly brought to completion to enable crops to be grown at an early date. No less than four thousand men are now engaged on the work. One of the most remarkable portions of the work is the pumping installation. Vast shops have been erected for the pumps and all the other kinds of mechanical works. Birch Bey is the great organiser and manager of this property. From the conversation which I had with him, he appeared to be quite satisfied with the progress that is being made and he stated that he had no doubt but that Sir Ernest Cassel would be equally satisfied.

div.head: MENZALEH CANAL & NAVIGATION CO.
div.p: The powerful new dredger for the Menzaleh Canal and Navigation Company has now been built, and it is expected that it will be at work in about a week's time. The order for the fleet of this company has been placed in the hands of the Anglo-American Nile Steamer and Hotel Company, who are charged with the whole of the order. The fleet will consist of six barges, two passenger steamers, and two tugs, and all these vessels will be built in England. They will be delivered by June 1, 1905. By that date it is hoped to open a portion of the canal (30 kilomètres) between Matarieh and Port Said. This will be a great advantage for pas- sengers. The Belgian company which has a light railway in this part of the Delta will run a service of specially quick trains from Mansourah to Matarieh in connection with the boats of the Menzaleh Company. The time occupied on the journey from Matarieh to Port Said will thus be shortened to five hours.
The immense possibilities for the develop- ment of the Sharkieh Province owing to this rapid communication are obvious.

div.head: PORT SAID DEVELOPMENT.
div.p: NEW HARBOUR WORKS.

At the end of last year the Suez Canal Company invited tenders for making two new basins on the Asiatic side of Port Said harbour, one of which was to accommodate the colliers that discharge there and, the other the petro- leum tank steamers.

Among the numerous tenders received from all parts of Europe, that sent in by the Société de Grands Travaux de Marseille was accepted. Including the additional or supplementary works that the Canal Company will carry out itself, the total cost of constructing these two new basins will amount to about three million franes, or £120,000. Once these basins are completed, that now known as the "Bassin Abbas," near the waterworks, on the African side, will be utilized for steamers generally, other than the colliers which at present use it exclusively.

The Suez Canal Company intends likewise to considerably imprové the two other basins, known by the names of the Bassin de l'Arsenal and the Bassin Chérif, on the same side of the shore, by enlarging and deepening them and adapting or making them available also for cargo steamers of the largest tonnage and draught. As a result of these improvements and changes the general workshops will have to be removed elsewhere. They will, at the same time, be much enlarged, remodelled, and improved. After a long study of this question the chief engineer of the company, now in Paris, recommended that the new buildings should be erected on the Asiatic side of the harbour, opposite the town, where sufficient space is available, and at this moment a definite project is before the directors for their approval.

On the other hand, a short time back the Canal Company imported three large porteurs, floating receivers or mud tanks, which are used, in connection with the powerful marine dredgers in the port. To increase the dredging operations necessary to keep the port at a uniform and requisite depth, the company has ordered another steamer dredger and mud tank combined, of the type known as the Puissante. Of the new floating dock recently arrived at Port Said from England we have already given & description,

div.head: MURDER IN A THEATRE.
div.p: A DASTARDLY OUTRAGE.
The Eden Music-hall at Alexandria, where the recent fire panic took place, was the scene last night of a dastardly outrage.

About 10.30 p.m., whilst the performance was going on, the ticket-collector was seen to t rush into the auditorium closely pursued by the man in charge of the box-office, of Greek nationality, who carried a dagger in his hand. The latter fell upon his victim and inflicted a deep wound in the back, from which the man fell in front of the stage. He attempted to rise and escape, but was furiously attacked twice and fell dying at the side entrance of the i theatre, leaving a trail of blood behind him. The audience, panic-striken, rushed to the exits of the theatre, and it was left to the fireman on duty to effect the capture of the murderer. The latter seized his belt axe and felled the man to the ground near his dying victim. The murderer, however, escaped the clutches of the fireman and was finally arrested as he emerged into the open street by the ghaffir on duty on a sign from the fireman, who blew his whistle.
The man so brutally attacked, who is an Italian, was removed to the Greek Hospital, but expired on the way. His assassin has been incarcerated at Labbane caracol pending his trial.
The motive of the crime has not as yet transpired, but it evidently arose from a violent quarrel which the two men had at the entrance of the theatre.
